an4.171:1.1.pli: “Kāye vā, bhikkhave, sati kāyasañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, as long as there’s a body, the intention that gives rise to bodily action causes pleasure and pain to arise in oneself.

an4.171:1.2.pli: Vācāya vā, bhikkhave, sati vacīsañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:1.2.eng: As long as there’s a voice, the intention that gives rise to verbal action causes pleasure and pain to arise in oneself.

an4.171:1.3.pli: Mane vā, bhikkhave, sati manosañcetanāhetu uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ avijjāpaccayāva.
an4.171:1.3.eng: As long as there’s a mind, the intention that gives rise to mental action causes pleasure and pain to arise in oneself. But this is only when dependent on ignorance.

an4.171:2.1.pli: Sāmaṃ vā taṃ, bhikkhave, kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:2.1.eng: By oneself one instigates the choice that gives rise to bodily, verbal, and mental action, conditioned by which that pleasure and pain arise in oneself.

an4.171:2.2.pli: Pare vāssa taṃ, bhikkhave, kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharonti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:2.2.eng: Or else others instigate the choice …

an4.171:2.3.pli: Sampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:2.3.eng: One instigates the choice after deliberation …

an4.171:2.4.pli: Asampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, kāyasaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.
an4.171:2.4.eng: Or else one instigates the choice without deliberation …

an4.171:3.1.pli: Sāmaṃ vā taṃ, bhikkhave, vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ;

an4.171:3.2.pli: pare vāssa taṃ, bhikkhave, vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharonti;

an4.171:3.4.pli: sampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ;

an4.171:3.5.pli: asampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, vacīsaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.

an4.171:4.1.pli: Sāmaṃ vā taṃ, bhikkhave, manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ;

an4.171:4.2.pli: pare vāssa taṃ, bhikkhave, manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharonti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ;

an4.171:4.3.pli: sampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ;

an4.171:4.4.pli: asampajāno vā taṃ, bhikkhave, manosaṅkhāraṃ abhisaṅkharoti, yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ.

an4.171:5.1.eng: Ignorance is included in all these things.

an4.171:5.2.pli: avijjāya tveva asesavirāganirodhā so kāyo na hoti yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ, sā vācā na hoti yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ, so mano na hoti yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhaṃ,
an4.171:5.2.eng: But when ignorance fades away and ceases with nothing left over, that body, that voice, and that mind no longer exist dependent on which that pleasure and pain arise in oneself.

an4.171:5.3.pli: khettaṃ taṃ na hoti …pe… vatthu taṃ na hoti …pe… āyatanaṃ taṃ na hoti …pe… adhikaraṇaṃ taṃ na hoti yaṃpaccayāssa taṃ uppajjati ajjhattaṃ sukhadukkhanti.
an4.171:5.3.eng: That field does not exist, that ground does not exist, that basis does not exist, that foundation does not exist, dependent on which that pleasure and pain arise in oneself.”

an4.171:6.1.eng: “Mendicants, there are four kinds of incarnation.

an4.171:6.3.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanā kamati, no parasañcetanā.
an4.171:6.3.eng: There is incarnation where one’s own intention is effective, not that of others.

an4.171:6.4.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe parasañcetanā kamati, no attasañcetanā.
an4.171:6.4.eng: There is incarnation where the intention of others is effective, not one’s own.

an4.171:6.5.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanā ca kamati parasañcetanā ca.
an4.171:6.5.eng: There is incarnation where both one’s own and others’ intentions are effective.

an4.171:6.6.pli: Atthi, bhikkhave, attabhāvapaṭilābho, yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe nevattasañcetanā kamati, no parasañcetanā.
an4.171:6.6.eng: There is incarnation where neither one’s own nor others’ intentions are effective.

an4.171:6.7.eng: These are the four kinds of incarnation.”

an4.171:7.1.pli: Evaṃ vutte, āyasmā sāriputto bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
an4.171:7.1.eng: When he said this, Venerable Sāriputta said to the Buddha:

an4.171:7.2.pli: “imassa kho ahaṃ, bhante, bhagavatā saṅkhittena bhāsitassa evaṃ vitthārena atthaṃ ājānāmi:
an4.171:7.2.eng: “Sir, this is how I understand the detailed meaning of the Buddha’s brief statement.

an4.171:7.3.pli: ‘tatra, bhante, yāyaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanā kamati no parasañcetanā, attasañcetanāhetu tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā kāyā cuti hoti.
an4.171:7.3.eng: Take the case of the incarnation where one’s own intention is effective, not that of others. Those sentient beings pass away from that realm due to their own intention.

an4.171:7.4.pli: Tatra, bhante, yāyaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe parasañcetanā kamati no attasañcetanā, parasañcetanāhetu tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā kāyā cuti hoti.
an4.171:7.4.eng: Take the case of the incarnation where the intention of others is effective, not one’s own. Those sentient beings pass away from that realm due to the intention of others.

an4.171:7.5.pli: Tatra, bhante, yāyaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe attasañcetanā ca kamati parasañcetanā ca, attasañcetanā ca parasañcetanā ca hetu tesaṃ sattānaṃ tamhā kāyā cuti hoti.
an4.171:7.5.eng: Take the case of the incarnation where both one’s own and others’ intentions are effective. Those sentient beings pass away from that realm due to both their own and others’ intentions.

an4.171:7.6.pli: Tatra, bhante, yāyaṃ attabhāvapaṭilābho yasmiṃ attabhāvapaṭilābhe neva attasañcetanā kamati no parasañcetanā, katame tena devā daṭṭhabbā’”ti?
an4.171:7.6.eng: But sir, in the case of the incarnation where neither one’s own nor others’ intentions are effective, what kind of gods does this refer to?”

an4.171:7.7.eng: “Sāriputta, it refers to the gods reborn in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.”

an4.171:8.1.pli: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā tamhā kāyā cutā āgāmino honti āgantāro itthattaṃ?
an4.171:8.1.eng: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why some sentient beings pass away from that realm as returners who come back to this place,

an4.171:8.2.pli: Ko pana, bhante, hetu ko paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā tamhā kāyā cutā anāgāmino honti anāgantāro itthattan”ti?
an4.171:8.2.eng: while others are non-returners who don’t come back?”

an4.171:8.3.pli: “Idha, sāriputta, ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni appahīnāni honti, so diṭṭheva dhamme nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.171:8.3.eng: “Sāriputta, take an individual who hasn’t given up the lower fetters. In this very life they enter and abide in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.171:8.4.pli: So tadassādeti, taṃ nikāmeti, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
an4.171:8.4.eng: They enjoy it and like it and find it rewarding.

an4.171:8.5.pli: tattha ṭhito tadadhimutto tabbahulavihārī aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an4.171:8.5.eng: If they abide in that, are committed to it, and meditate on it often without losing it, when they die they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.171:8.6.pli: So tato cuto āgāmī hoti āgantā itthattaṃ.
an4.171:8.6.eng: When they pass away from there, they’re a returner, who comes back to this place.

an4.171:9.1.pli: Idha pana, sāriputta, ekaccassa puggalassa orambhāgiyāni saṃyojanāni pahīnāni honti, so diṭṭheva dhamme nevasaññānāsaññāyatanaṃ upasampajja viharati.
an4.171:9.1.eng: Sāriputta, take an individual who has given up the lower fetters. In this very life they enter and abide in the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.171:9.2.pli: So tadassādeti, taṃ nikāmeti, tena ca vittiṃ āpajjati;
an4.171:9.2.eng: They enjoy it and like it and find it rewarding.

an4.171:9.3.pli: tattha ṭhito tadadhimutto tabbahulavihārī aparihīno kālaṃ kurumāno nevasaññānāsaññāyatanūpagānaṃ devānaṃ sahabyataṃ upapajjati.
an4.171:9.3.eng: If they abide in that, are committed to it, and meditate on it often without losing it, when they die they’re reborn in the company of the gods of the dimension of neither perception nor non-perception.

an4.171:9.4.pli: So tato cuto anāgāmī hoti anāgantā itthattaṃ.
an4.171:9.4.eng: When they pass away from there, they’re a non-returner, not coming back to this place.

an4.171:10.1.pli: Ayaṃ kho, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā tamhā kāyā cutā āgāmino honti āgantāro itthattaṃ.
an4.171:10.1.eng: This is the cause, this is the reason why some sentient beings pass away from that realm as returners who come back to this place,

an4.171:10.2.pli: Ayaṃ pana, sāriputta, hetu ayaṃ paccayo, yena m’idhekacce sattā tamhā kāyā cutā anāgāmino honti anāgantāro itthattan”ti.
an4.171:10.2.eng: while others are non-returners who don’t come back.”

an4.172:1.1.pli: Tatra kho āyasmā sāriputto bhikkhū āmantesi:

an4.172:1.3.pli: “Āvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū āyasmato sāriputtassa paccassosuṃ.

an4.172:2.1.pli: “Addhamāsūpasampannena me, āvuso, atthapaṭisambhidā sacchikatā odhiso byañjanaso.
an4.172:2.1.eng: “Reverends, I realized the textual analysis of the meaning—piece by piece and expression by expression—a fortnight after I ordained.

an4.172:2.2.pli: Tamahaṃ anekapariyāyena ācikkhāmi desemi paññāpemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi.
an4.172:2.2.eng: In many ways I explain, teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal it.

an4.172:2.3.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, so maṃ pañhena.
an4.172:2.3.eng: Whoever has any doubt or uncertainty, let them ask me,

an4.172:2.4.pli: Ahaṃ veyyākaraṇena sammukhībhūto no satthā yo no dhammānaṃ sukusalo.
an4.172:2.4.eng: I will answer. Our teacher is present, he who is so very skilled in our teachings.

an4.172:3.1.pli: Addhamāsūpasampannena me, āvuso, dhammapaṭisambhidā sacchikatā odhiso byañjanaso.
an4.172:3.1.eng: I realized the textual analysis of the text—piece by piece and expression by expression—a fortnight after I ordained. …

an4.172:3.2.pli: Tamahaṃ anekapariyāyena ācikkhāmi desemi paññāpemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi.

an4.172:3.3.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, so maṃ pañhena.

an4.172:3.4.pli: Ahaṃ veyyākaraṇena sammukhībhūto no satthā yo no dhammānaṃ sukusalo.

an4.172:4.1.pli: Addhamāsūpasampannena me, āvuso, niruttipaṭisambhidā sacchikatā odhiso byañjanaso.
an4.172:4.1.eng: I realized the textual analysis of definition—piece by piece and expression by expression—a fortnight after I ordained. …

an4.172:4.2.pli: Tamahaṃ anekapariyāyena ācikkhāmi desemi paññāpemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi.

an4.172:4.3.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, so maṃ pañhena.

an4.172:4.4.pli: Ahaṃ veyyākaraṇena sammukhībhūto no satthā yo no dhammānaṃ sukusalo.

an4.172:5.1.pli: Addhamāsūpasampannena me, āvuso, paṭibhānapaṭisambhidā sacchikatā odhiso byañjanaso.
an4.172:5.1.eng: I realized the textual analysis of eloquence—piece by piece and expression by expression—a fortnight after I ordained.

an4.172:5.2.pli: Tamahaṃ anekapariyāyena ācikkhāmi desemi paññāpemi paṭṭhapemi vivarāmi vibhajāmi uttānīkaromi.
an4.172:5.2.eng: In many ways I explain, teach, assert, establish, clarify, analyze, and reveal it.

an4.172:5.3.pli: Yassa kho panassa kaṅkhā vā vimati vā, so maṃ pañhena.
an4.172:5.3.eng: If anyone has any doubt or uncertainty, let them ask me,

an4.172:5.4.pli: Ahaṃ veyyākaraṇena sammukhībhūto no satthā yo no dhammānaṃ sukusalo”ti.
an4.172:5.4.eng: I will answer. Our teacher is present, he who is so very skilled in our teachings.”

an4.173:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.173:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.173:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.173:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Mahākoṭṭhita sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:

an4.173:2.1.eng: “Reverend, when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, does something else still exist?”

an4.173:6.1.pli: “Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī”ti?
an4.173:6.1.eng: “Does something else both still exist and no longer exist?”

an4.173:8.1.pli: “Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī”ti?
an4.173:8.1.eng: “Does something else neither still exist nor no longer exist?”

an4.173:10.1.pli: “‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno ‘mā hevaṃ, āvuso’ti vadesi.
an4.173:10.1.eng: “Reverend, when asked whether—when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over—something else still exists, you say ‘don’t put it like that’.

an4.173:10.2.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
an4.173:10.2.eng: When asked whether something else no longer exists,

an4.173:10.3.eng: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.

an4.173:10.4.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
an4.173:10.4.eng: When asked whether something else both still exists and no longer exists,

an4.173:10.5.eng: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.

an4.173:10.6.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
an4.173:10.6.eng: When asked whether something else neither still exists nor no longer exists,

an4.173:10.7.eng: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.

an4.173:10.8.pli: Yathā kathaṃ pana, āvuso, imassa bhāsitassa attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
an4.173:10.8.eng: How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

an4.173:11.1.pli: “‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.173:11.1.eng: “In saying that, ‘When the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, something else still exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.173:11.2.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.173:11.2.eng: In saying that, ‘something else no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.173:11.3.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.173:11.3.eng: In saying that, ‘something else both still exists and no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.173:11.4.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.173:11.4.eng: In saying that, ‘something else neither still exists nor no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.173:11.5.pli: Yāvatā, āvuso, channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ gati tāvatā papañcassa gati;
an4.173:11.5.eng: The scope of proliferation extends as far as the scope of the six fields of contact.

an4.173:11.6.pli: yāvatā papañcassa gati tāvatā channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ gati.
an4.173:11.6.eng: The scope of the six fields of contact extends as far as the scope of proliferation.

an4.173:11.7.pli: Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā papañcanirodho papañcavūpasamo”ti.
an4.173:11.7.eng: When the six fields of contact fade away and cease with nothing left over, proliferation stops and is stilled.”

an4.174:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yenāyasmā mahākoṭṭhiko tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā mahākoṭṭhikena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.174:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Ānanda went up to Venerable Mahākoṭṭhita, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.174:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando āyasmantaṃ mahākoṭṭhikaṃ etadavoca:
an4.174:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Ānanda sat down to one side, and said to Mahākoṭṭhita:

an4.174:2.1.eng: “Reverend, when these six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, does something else exist?”

an4.174:6.1.pli: “Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī”ti?
an4.174:6.1.eng: “Does something else both still exist and no longer exist?”

an4.174:8.1.pli: “Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī”ti?
an4.174:8.1.eng: “Does something else neither still exist nor no longer exist?”

an4.174:10.1.pli: “‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.174:10.2.eng: you say ‘don’t put it like that’.

an4.174:10.3.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.174:10.5.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.174:10.7.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.174:10.9.pli: Yathā kathaṃ panāvuso, imassa bhāsitassa attho daṭṭhabbo”ti?
an4.174:10.9.eng: … How then should we see the meaning of this statement?”

an4.174:11.1.pli: “‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.174:11.1.eng: “In saying that, ‘when the six fields of contact have faded away and ceased with nothing left over, something else exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.174:11.2.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.174:11.2.eng: In saying that, ‘something else no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.174:11.3.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā atthi ca natthi ca aññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.174:11.3.eng: In saying that, ‘something else both still exists and no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.174:11.4.pli: ‘Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā nevatthi no natthaññaṃ kiñcī’ti, iti vadaṃ appapañcaṃ papañceti.
an4.174:11.4.eng: In saying that, ‘something else neither still exists nor no longer exists’, you’re proliferating the unproliferated.

an4.174:11.5.pli: Yāvatā, āvuso, channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ gati tāvatā papañcassa gati.
an4.174:11.5.eng: The scope of proliferation extends as far as the scope of the six fields of contact.

an4.174:11.6.pli: Yāvatā papañcassa gati tāvatā channaṃ phassāyatanānaṃ gati.
an4.174:11.6.eng: The scope of the six fields of contact extends as far as the scope of proliferation.

an4.174:11.7.pli: Channaṃ, āvuso, phassāyatanānaṃ asesavirāganirodhā papañcanirodho papañcavūpasamo”ti.
an4.174:11.7.eng: When the six fields of contact fade away and cease with nothing left over, proliferation stops and is stilled.”

an4.175:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā upavāṇo yenāyasmā sāriputto tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā āyasmatā sāriputtena saddhiṃ sammodi.
an4.175:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Upavāṇa went up to Venerable Sāriputta, and exchanged greetings with him.

an4.175:1.2.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā upavāṇo āyasmantaṃ sāriputtaṃ etadavoca:
an4.175:1.2.eng: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, Upavāṇa sat down to one side, and said to Sāriputta:

an4.175:2.1.pli: “Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, vijjāyantakaro hotī”ti?
an4.175:2.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, do you become a terminator because of knowledge?”

an4.175:4.1.eng: “Do you become a terminator because of conduct?”

an4.175:6.1.eng: “Do you become a terminator because of both knowledge and conduct?”

an4.175:8.1.eng: “Do you become a terminator for some reason other than knowledge and conduct?”

an4.175:10.1.pli: “‘Kiṃ nu kho, āvuso sāriputta, vijjāyantakaro hotī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:
an4.175:10.1.eng: “Reverend Sāriputta, when asked whether you become a terminator because of knowledge or conduct or knowledge and conduct, or for some other reason,

an4.175:10.3.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, caraṇenantakaro hotī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.175:10.5.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, vijjācaraṇenantakaro hotī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.175:10.7.pli: ‘Kiṃ panāvuso sāriputta, aññatra vijjācaraṇenantakaro hotī’ti, iti puṭṭho samāno:

an4.175:10.9.eng: How then do you become a terminator?”

an4.175:11.1.pli: “Vijjāya ce, āvuso, antakaro abhavissa, saupādānova samāno antakaro abhavissa.
an4.175:11.1.eng: “Reverend, if you became a terminator because of knowledge, then even someone who still has fuel for grasping could be a terminator.

an4.175:11.2.pli: Caraṇena ce, āvuso, antakaro abhavissa, saupādānova samāno antakaro abhavissa.
an4.175:11.2.eng: If you became a terminator because of conduct, then even someone who still has fuel for grasping could be a terminator.

an4.175:11.3.pli: Vijjācaraṇena ce, āvuso, antakaro abhavissa, saupādānova samāno antakaro abhavissa.
an4.175:11.3.eng: If you became a terminator because of both knowledge and conduct, then even someone who still has fuel for grasping could be a terminator.

an4.175:11.4.pli: Aññatra vijjācaraṇena ce, āvuso, antakaro abhavissa, puthujjano antakaro abhavissa.
an4.175:11.4.eng: If you became a terminator for some reason other than knowledge and conduct, then even an ordinary person could be a terminator.

an4.175:11.5.eng: For an ordinary person lacks knowledge and conduct.

an4.175:11.6.pli: Caraṇavipanno kho, āvuso, yathābhūtaṃ na jānāti na passati.
an4.175:11.6.eng: Reverend, someone lacking good conduct does not know and see things as they are.

an4.175:11.7.eng: Someone accomplished in good conduct knows and sees things as they are.

an4.175:11.8.eng: Knowing and seeing things as they are, one is a terminator.”

an4.176:1.1.pli: “Saddho, bhikkhave, bhikkhu evaṃ sammā āyācamāno āyāceyya:
an4.176:1.1.eng: “Mendicants, a faithful monk would rightly aspire:

an4.176:1.2.eng: ‘May I be like Sāriputta and Moggallāna!’

an4.176:1.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvakānaṃ bhikkhūnaṃ, yadidaṃ sāriputtamoggallānā.
an4.176:1.3.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my monk disciples, that is, Sāriputta and Moggallāna.

an4.176:2.1.pli: Saddhā, bhikkhave, bhikkhunī evaṃ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
an4.176:2.1.eng: A faithful nun would rightly aspire:

an4.176:2.2.pli: ‘tādisā homi yādisā khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā cā’ti.
an4.176:2.2.eng: ‘May I be like the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā!’

an4.176:2.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvikānaṃ bhikkhunīnaṃ, yadidaṃ khemā ca bhikkhunī uppalavaṇṇā ca.
an4.176:2.3.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my nun disciples, that is, the nuns Khemā and Uppalavaṇṇā.

an4.176:3.1.pli: Saddho, bhikkhave, upāsako evaṃ sammā āyācamāno āyāceyya:
an4.176:3.1.eng: A faithful layman would rightly aspire:

an4.176:3.2.pli: ‘tādiso homi yādiso citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako’ti.
an4.176:3.2.eng: ‘May I be like the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Āḷavī!’

an4.176:3.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvakānaṃ upāsakānaṃ, yadidaṃ citto ca gahapati hatthako ca āḷavako.
an4.176:3.3.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my male lay disciples, that is, the householder Citta and Hatthaka of Āḷavī.

an4.176:4.1.pli: Saddhā, bhikkhave, upāsikā evaṃ sammā āyācamānā āyāceyya:
an4.176:4.1.eng: A faithful laywoman would rightly aspire:

an4.176:4.2.pli: ‘tādisā homi yādisā khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā’ti.
an4.176:4.2.eng: ‘May I be like the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother!’

an4.176:4.3.pli: Esā, bhikkhave, tulā etaṃ pamāṇaṃ mama sāvikānaṃ upāsikānaṃ, yadidaṃ khujjuttarā ca upāsikā veḷukaṇḍakiyā ca nandamātā”ti.
an4.176:4.3.eng: These are a standard and a measure for my female lay disciples, that is, the laywomen Khujjuttarā and Veḷukaṇṭakī, Nanda’s mother.”

an4.177:1.1.pli: Atha kho āyasmā rāhulo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinnaṃ kho āyasmantaṃ rāhulaṃ bhagavā etadavoca:
an4.177:1.1.eng: Then Venerable Rāhula went up to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to him:

an4.177:2.1.pli: “Yā ca, rāhula, ajjhattikā pathavīdhātu yā ca bāhirā pathavīdhātu, pathavīdhāturevesā.
an4.177:2.1.eng: “Rāhula, the interior earth element and the exterior earth element are just the earth element.

an4.177:2.2.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti, evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an4.177:2.2.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.177:2.3.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā pathavīdhātuyā nibbindati, pathavīdhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
an4.177:2.3.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the earth element, detaching the mind from the earth element.

an4.177:3.1.pli: Yā ca, rāhula, ajjhattikā āpodhātu yā ca bāhirā āpodhātu, āpodhāturevesā.
an4.177:3.1.eng: The interior water element and the exterior water element are just the water element.

an4.177:3.2.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti, evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an4.177:3.2.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.177:3.3.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā āpodhātuyā nibbindati, āpodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
an4.177:3.3.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the water element, detaching the mind from the water element.

an4.177:4.1.pli: Yā ca, rāhula, ajjhattikā tejodhātu yā ca bāhirā tejodhātu, tejodhāturevesā.
an4.177:4.1.eng: The interior fire element and the exterior fire element are just the fire element.

an4.177:4.2.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti, evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an4.177:4.2.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.177:4.3.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā tejodhātuyā nibbindati, tejodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
an4.177:4.3.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the fire element, detaching the mind from the fire element.

an4.177:5.1.pli: Yā ca, rāhula, ajjhattikā vāyodhātu yā ca bāhirā vāyodhātu, vāyodhāturevesā.
an4.177:5.1.eng: The interior air element and the exterior air element are just the air element.

an4.177:5.2.pli: ‘Taṃ netaṃ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti, evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṃ.
an4.177:5.2.eng: This should be truly seen with right understanding like this: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’

an4.177:5.3.pli: Evametaṃ yathābhūtaṃ sammappaññāya disvā vāyodhātuyā nibbindati, vāyodhātuyā cittaṃ virājeti.
an4.177:5.3.eng: When you truly see with right understanding, you grow disillusioned with the air element, detaching the mind from the air element.

an4.177:6.1.pli: Yato kho, rāhula, bhikkhu imāsu catūsu dhātūsu nevattānaṃ na attaniyaṃ samanupassati, ayaṃ vuccati, rāhula, bhikkhu acchecchi taṇhaṃ, vivattayi saṃyojanaṃ, sammā mānābhisamayā antamakāsi dukkhassā”ti.
an4.177:6.1.eng: When a mendicant sees these four elements as neither self nor belonging to self, they’re called a mendicant who has cut off craving, cast off the fetters, and by rightly comprehending conceit has made an end of suffering.”
